repnme.cdata!:
Russia - Urban Transport and Bridge
            Rehabilitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit largely concurs with the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR) ratings for both
            projects, on satisfactory project outcomes, (in spite of the
            ICR Review rating of moderately satisfactory), on modest
            institutional development impacts, and on a likely
            sustainability, in addition to the satisfactory ratings for
            both performances by the Bank and Borrower. The assessment
            shows the difficulties of implementing projects affected by
            a major exogenous shock, and a number of lessons can be
            drawn on how problems were addressed. To summarize, lessons
            suggest the following: 1) the formulation of realistic and
            measurable project objectives is crucial, and when there is
            a major restructuring of a project, the task team should
            take the opportunity to review the original objectives in
            light of changed circumstances; 2) Bank supervision
            arrangements should be realistic, and budgets should be
            higher when projects are decentralized, or spread over a
            wide area involving more than one implementing agency.
            Project design should take this into account; 3) covenants
            should not be imposed on authorities that do not have the
            legal power to carry out the commitment. Weak or open-ended
            conditionality should be avoided, and objectives should not
            be conflicting; and, 4) it is unwise to involve local,
            sub-national borrowers with the foreign exchange risks in
            unstable macroeconomic conditions, especially when their
            revenues are in the local currency.

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is overall satisfactory,
            and sustainability is likely. The performances of the Bank
            and the Borrower were overall satisfactory. Four out of six
            lessons drawn from this Project concern the imperative of
            striving for coherence, first within the project design
            itself (i.e. between its objectives, instruments, measures
            of performance, legal stipulations), then between the
            project design on paper and the reality of activities and
            relations in the field ("external" coherence), and
            finally the relation of both of these to the project budget.
            These lessons are not new, and some corrective actions in
            terms of operational policies have been taken since this
            Project was approved, notably the use of design aids such as
            the LogFrame. Still, the subject being difficult, presenting
            these lessons is warranted, even if some repetition is
            involved, especially if the examples involve the
            "external" coherence and relations to the budget.
            !) The first lesson has to do with a comparison between the
            efforts (resources) expanded under a project for some
            activity and the importance that activity has in the
            objectives and outcomes scheme. It stands to reason that
            activities which consume large resources should be reflected
            in the project design as explicit entries in the objectives
            and outcomes framework. 2) The second lesson involves a
            situation which is the inverse of the preceding one, i.e.
            that an activity present in the objectives and outcomes
            framework does not have a realistic budgetary dimension. The
            follow-up activities could not have been much more intense,
            given the number of cities and the distances involved. This
            has posed multiple problems with supervision, first because
            the absence of frequent contacts reduces the policy
            interaction with the clients, and also for the monitoring of
            outcomes (the two are linked). The supervision budgets being
            largely given and modest at best, the difficult lesson of
            this experience is that the policy focus of projects should
            be placed where a solid supervision presence is assured. 3)
            The third lesson concerns the links between the policy
            agenda and the institutional power to make the relevant
            changes. The lesson is to place the onus of a condition
            where there is power to make a change.  4) The fourth lesson
            has to do with weak conditionality, which is a notable
            feature of the Loan Agreement for this Project.5) The fifth
            lesson has to do with economic evaluation of investments
            involving fleet replacement and expansion for public
            transport services. Doing post-investment evaluation of
            fleet replacement in the context of Bank lending requires a
            considerable and expensive effort, which should be
            anticipated while projects are prepared and negotiated, and
            recorded formally in loan/project agreements. 6) The sixth
            lesson is drawn from the experience with sub-loan arrears in
            1999, following the collapse of the ruble against the
            dollar. Most of the client cities had no recourse but to
            step out of the Project. The Bank 's standard advice to
            the client governments is not to pass the foreign exchange
            risk to sub-national entities whose revenue sources are
            limited to domestic currency. A compromise was made in this
            project, at the insistence of the finance ministry, and it
            would have been preferable not to do this.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Transport Project will: 1)
            preserve essential urban transport capacity in 14 cities by
            linking financing of urgently needed replacement vehicles
            and spare parts to the implementation of reforms; 2)
            strengthen the 14 project cities' urban transport
            sector institutions so as to improve the efficiency of
            passenger transport operations; 3) arrest the decline of
            urban transport services in cities throughout Russia through
            the provision of urgently needed spare parts for transport
            vehicles; and 4) provide restructuring advice for the
            doemstic bus industry. The project will also serve to
            demonstrate the benefits of such reform programs to other
            cities in Russia and how Government support for capital
            replacement of vehicles could be tied to improved cost
            recovery and other reforms. Such reforms are needed on a
            national level to reduce urban transport losses. The project
            comprises three major components. The first component
            provides assistance for 14 self-selected cities to finance a
            large part of required fleet replacements for a three year
            period including financing for diesel fueled buses and
            trolleybuses, and rehabilitation of buses, trolley buses and
            trams; provision of workshop, computers and other equipment
            for urban transit companies plus a fare collection system to
            be tested in one of the project cities; and technical
            assistance and training to assist the cities implement
            reforms and assist with procurement and monitoring of the
            project. The second component provides assistance for the
            Ministry of Transportation (MOT) including: ten natural gas
            fueled buses; equipment for the Project Implementation
            Directorate (PID) studies of, and restructuring advice for,
            the domestic bus manufacturing industry; technical
            assistance and training to assist MOT develop more
            appropriate urban transport policies for cities throughout
            Russia; and help expand the reform program to other cities.
            The last component provides for the provision of spare parts
            for transit companies throughout Russia.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Transport Project will: 1)
            preserve essential urban transport capacity in 14 cities by
            linking financing of urgently needed replacement vehicles
            and spare parts to the implementation of reforms; 2)
            strengthen the 14 project cities' urban transport
            sector institutions so as to improve the efficiency of
            passenger transport operations; 3) arrest the decline of
            urban transport services in cities throughout Russia through
            the provision of urgently needed spare parts for transport
            vehicles; and 4) provide restructuring advice for the
            doemstic bus industry. The project will also serve to
            demonstrate the benefits of such reform programs to other
            cities in Russia and how Government support for capital
            replacement of vehicles could be tied to improved cost
            recovery and other reforms. Such reforms are needed on a
            national level to reduce urban transport losses. The project
            comprises three major components. The first component
            provides assistance for 14 self-selected cities to finance a
            large part of required fleet replacements for a three year
            period including financing for diesel fueled buses and
            trolleybuses, and rehabilitation of buses, trolley buses and
            trams; provision of workshop, computers and other equipment
            for urban transit companies plus a fare collection system to
            be tested in one of the project cities; and technical
            assistance and training to assist the cities implement
            reforms and assist with procurement and monitoring of the
            project. The second component provides assistance for the
            Ministry of Transportation (MOT) including: ten natural gas
            fueled buses; equipment for the Project Implementation
            Directorate (PID) studies of, and restructuring advice for,
            the domestic bus manufacturing industry; technical
            assistance and training to assist MOT develop more
            appropriate urban transport policies for cities throughout
            Russia; and help expand the reform program to other cities.
            The last component provides for the provision of spare parts
            for transit companies throughout Russia.

display_title.display_title:
Российская Федерация – проект
            развития городского транспорта
